UNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE INTERNATIONAL EXAMINATIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 115, 477, 129]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 130, 613, 145]]<|/det|>
Advanced Subsidiary Level and Advanced Level

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 195, 220, 207]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 195, 907, 207]]<|/det|>
9709/11

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 217, 907, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1) **October/November 2011**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 239, 907, 252]]<|/det|>
**1 hour 45 minutes**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 259, 460, 273]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 273, 400, 286]]<|/det|>
Graph Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 287, 463, 301]]<|/det|>
List of Formulae (MF9)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 323, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 382]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 398]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 495, 414]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 461]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 492]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 589, 508]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 606, 554]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 756, 570]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 440, 586]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 907, 617]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 865, 660, 879]]<|/det|>
This document consists of **4** printed pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 625, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(2x + \frac{1}{x^2}\right)^6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 138, 97, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 900, 156]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 3x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 4x + 2\). Show that the gradient of the curve is never negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 153, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 200, 94, 219]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 200, 784, 220]]<|/det|>
(i) Sketch, on a single diagram, the graphs of \(y = \cos 2\theta\) and \(y = \frac{1}{2}\) for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 201, 920, 219]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 231, 151, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 231, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
Write down the number of roots of the equation \(2\cos 2\theta - 1 = 0\) in the interval \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\pi\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 151, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 262, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
Deduce the number of roots of the equation \(2\cos 2\theta - 1 = 0\) in the interval \(10\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant 20\pi\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 310, 94, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
A function f is defined for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) and is such that \(\mathrm{f}^{\prime}(x) = 2x - 6\). The range of the function is given by \(\mathrm{f}(x) \geqslant -4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 355, 151, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 355, 613, 373]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(x\) for which \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) has a stationary value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 386, 151, 404]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 386, 485, 404]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 386, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 432, 94, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 440, 740, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 637, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
The diagram represents a metal plate \(OABC\), consisting of a sector \(OAB\) of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(r\), together with a triangle \(OCB\) which is right-angled at \(C\). Angle \(AOB = \theta\) radians and \(OC\) is perpendicular to \(OA\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 700, 153, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 700, 702, 718]]<|/det|>
Find an expression in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\) for the perimeter of the plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 732, 153, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 732, 665, 750]]<|/det|>
For the case where \(r = 10\) and \(\theta = \frac{1}{5}\pi\), find the area of the plate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 732, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 781, 96, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 781, 144, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 781, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
The sixth term of an arithmetic progression is 23 and the sum of the first ten terms is 200. Find the seventh term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 797, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 828, 146, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 826, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has first term 1 and common ratio \(r\). A second geometric progression has first term 4 and common ratio \(\frac{1}{4} r\). The two progressions have the same sum to infinity, \(S\). Find the values of \(r\) and \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 84, 737, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 285, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the dimensions in metres of an L-shaped garden. The perimeter of the garden is \(48 \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 333, 156, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 333, 465, 352]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 333, 918, 352]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 364, 151, 382]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 364, 690, 382]]<|/det|>
Given that the area of the garden is \(A \mathrm{~m}^2\), show that \(A = 48x - 8x^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 364, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 148, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x\) can vary, find the maximum area of the garden, showing that this is a maximum value rather than a minimum value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 457, 96, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 457, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
Relative to an origin \(O\), the point \(A\) has position vector \(4\mathbf{i} + 7\mathbf{j} - p\mathbf{k}\) and the point \(B\) has position vector \(8\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - p\mathbf{k}\), where \(p\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 505, 156, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 272, 524]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OA}.\overrightarrow{OB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 537, 153, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 537, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
Hence show that there are no real values of \(p\) for which \(OA\) and \(OB\) are perpendicular to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 153, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 584, 549, 603]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(p\) for which angle \(AOB = 60^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 585, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 631, 96, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 631, 873, 650]]<|/det|>
A line has equation \(y = kx + 6\) and a curve has equation \(y = x^{2} + 3x + 2k\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 662, 153, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 662, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
For the case where \(k = 2\), the line and the curve intersect at points \(A\) and \(B\). Find the distance \(AB\) and the coordinates of the mid-point of \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 710, 153, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 710, 697, 727]]<|/det|>
Find the two values of \(k\) for which the line is a tangent to the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 816, 715, 836]]<|/det|>
[Questions 10 and 11 are printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 81, 856, 357]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 377, 920, 412]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = \sqrt{(1 + 2x)}\) meeting the \(x\)-axis at \(A\) and the \(y\)-axis at \(B\). The \(y\)-coordinate of the point \(C\) on the curve is 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 424, 154, 442]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 424, 420, 442]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(B\) and \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 424, 920, 442]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 454, 153, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 454, 554, 472]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal to the curve at \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 151, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 485, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Find the volume obtained when the shaded region is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(y\)-axis. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 532, 104, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 376, 551]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 556, 645, 575]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}:x\mapsto 2x^{2} - 8x + 10\quad \mathrm{for} 0\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 579, 653, 598]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}:x\mapsto x\qquad \mathrm{for} 0\leqslant x\leqslant 10.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 618, 154, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 618, 715, 636]]<|/det|>
Express \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) in the form \(a(x + b)^2 + c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 618, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 650, 153, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 650, 319, 668]]<|/det|>
State the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 650, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 680, 151, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 680, 351, 698]]<|/det|>
State the domain of \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 711, 153, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 711, 920, 746]]<|/det|>
Sketch on the same diagram the graphs of \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\), \(y = \operatorname {g}(x)\) and \(y = \operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\), making clear the relationship between the graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 727, 920, 746]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 758, 151, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 758, 398, 777]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 758, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
